Rule1: One of the rules of the game is that if the crab does not trade one of its pieces with the llama, then the llama will never swim in the pool next to the house of the stork. Rule2: If you see that something does not swim in the pool next to the house of the mouse and also does not fall on a square of the goose, what can you certainly conclude? You can conclude that it also swims inside the pool located besides the house of the stork. Rule1 is preferred over Rule2. Based on the game state and the rules and preferences, does the llama swim in the pool next to the house of the stork?
proof: We know the llama does not swim in the pool next to the house of the mouse and the llama does not fall on a square of the goose, and according to Rule2 "if something does not swim in the pool next to the house of the mouse and does not fall on a square of the goose, then it swims in the pool next to the house of the stork", and for the conflicting and higher priority rule Rule1 we cannot prove the antecedent "the crab does not trade one of its pieces with the llama", so we can conclude "the llama swims in the pool next to the house of the stork". So the statement "the llama swims in the pool next to the house of the stork" is proved and the answer is "yes".
theory:
Facts:
	~(llama, fall, goose)
	~(llama, swim, mouse)
Rules:
	Rule1: ~(crab, trade, llama) => ~(llama, swim, stork)
	Rule2: ~(X, swim, mouse)^~(X, fall, goose) => (X, swim, stork)
Preferences:
	Rule1 > Rule2
label: proved
